instance_metrics.response: Dear love, for nothing less than thee  Would I entreat the turning skies—  Not morning’s gold, nor midnight’s plea  Could stir such longing in my eyes.  The silent hush of autumn rain,  The breaking song of early light,  Are pale as ghosts, are soft and vain  Beside thy presence, full and bright.For what is earth, if not the place  Where first I saw thy gentle face?  And what is time, but hours spun  To weave our hearts, to make us one?  No jewel, no crown, no poet’s art  Could tempt my soul or claim my heart;  All kingdoms fade, all riches flee—  I ask for nothing less than thee.Let storms arise, let shadows fall,  Let tempests shake the distant sea;  Within thy arms, I have my all—  Dear love, for nothing less than thee.  So let the world its fortune keep,  And let the stars their secrets hide;  My truest treasure lies so deep  Where hope and faith in love abide.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

instance_metrics.response: Dear love, for nothing less than thee  Would I unravel night’s embrace,  Nor barter dawn’s tranquility  For any star’s unsteady grace.  The world may tilt on axes cold,  And time may rust the gilded years,  But in my heart, a flame I hold  That burns away my fears.  No summer sun, nor harvest moon,  Could coax my gaze from seeking thine;  No jeweled promise, rich or soon,  Could tempt me from this sacred line.  I measure days in whispered names,  In silent prayers, in hope’s decree—  Dear love, my every dream proclaims  There is no world but thee.  Let tempests rage and roses fade,  Let fortune’s fickle hand depart,  Still in the quiet dusk we’ve made,  Your shadow warms my heart.  And should the heavens split apart  And cast the stars into the sea,  I’d gather them, a trembling art—  For nothing less than thee.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

instance_metrics.response: Dear love, for nothing less than thee  Could move the silent tides in me—  Not moon nor sun nor distant star  Commands my soul the way you are.  No gilded promise, fleeting bright,  No velvet word that dims with night,  Could rouse my heart from gentle sleep  Or stir the dreams I dare to keep.  For you, my every breath is cast  Like petals on the river’s glass;  For you, I hold the world at bay  And gather hope from common day.  A glance, a sigh, a fleeting touch—  Each moment, dear, reveals so much:  The quiet pulse of longing’s fire,  The hush of deeply-rooted desire.  I seek no glory, wealth, nor fame,  No other whispers call my name—  But yours, the music soft and low  That bids the smallest seed to grow.  So let the seasons turn and flee;  Let time unwind its mystery—  My heart, unbarred, will always be  Yours, dear love, for nothing less than thee.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

instance_metrics.response: Dear love, for nothing less than thee  Would I unmoor my quiet heart—  No lesser star could summon me  To sail from shore and drift apart.  For nothing less than thee, my flame,  Could rouse the hush of midnight’s air,  Could make the silent world proclaim  A song that only we can share.  Not golden fields, nor silver skies,  Nor all the honeyed words I know,  Could tempt the longing in my eyes  To anywhere but where you go.  For in the hush between our words  A truth unspoken, fierce and free,  Takes root and spreads like singing birds—  Dear love, for nothing less than thee.  No time, nor fate, nor distance wide  Could thin the thread that draws me near;  Within your gaze, my fears subside,  And all the world grows sharp and clear.  So take this heart, my only plea:  Let all I am and hope to be  Rest in your hands, eternally—  Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

instance_metrics.response: ’Twas noontide of summer, the fields lay at rest,  A hush of gold slumbered on valley and crest,  The wildflowers nodded in shimmering heat,  And time seemed to soften beneath my bare feet.  The sun in its fullness had conquered the sky,  Each blade of green grass sang a slow lullaby.  The bees in their labor droned heavy and low,  While drowsy cicadas set pulses aglow.  Beneath the old willow, cool shadows were cast,  An island of solace from sunlight amassed.  I lay in the hush with my eyes drifting closed,  The world in its stillness so perfectly posed.  The river beyond wore a garment of light,  Its ripples like laughter that danced out of sight,  And somewhere a bluebird, half-hidden, half-seen,  Trilled sweet, fleeting notes in the hush in between.  ’Twas noontide of summer—the threshold of dreams,  When everything pauses and quietly gleams,  And memory gathers the warmth of the day  To carry its gold through the year’s slow decay.

The river lay drowsing, a mirror of sky,  Clouds drifting idly through blue, endless domes;  Cicadas intoned their hot, tireless cry,  And far-off the lowing of cattle comes home.  Each leaf was ablaze, every pebble a spark,  The heat shimmered upwards in rippling waves;  Barefoot, I wandered the meadow’s bright arc,  A moth in the honeyed perfume it gave.  The orchard was heavy with promise and sweet,  Apples and cherries, their skins flushed with flame;  A hush held the hedgerows, the dust on the street—  Stillness itself seemed to whisper my name.  ’Twas noontide of summer, the zenith of days,  Time paused, suspended in luminous haze;  I gathered the gold in my hands, in my eyes,  And dreamed of the sun while the summer sky sighed.

The air tasted honey and clover and thyme,  A slow, lazy perfume that hovered and stayed;  Cicadas kept time to the heart’s gentle rhyme,  While the wild roses blushed in the drowsy parade.  No wind dared to wander, no cloud dimmed the blue—  All motion was softened, all voices were still,  Save the distant, soft laughter of children who knew  That magic is born when the daylight stands still.  ’Twas noontide of summer, a moment apart,  Where time drifted softly like thistledown spun—  A shimmering peace settling deep in the heart,  A golden forever beneath the bright sun.

They tally their numbers at midnight,  Filling my room with invisible weight,  Each one a possibility, sharp as a pin,  Each one a lock on a trembling gate.  They perch on the sill of my reason,  Fluttering wings made of old regrets,  Rattling windows with anxious wind,  Watering roots of what never forgets.  My God, how many are my fears!  A choir with a thousand throats—  They sing of all that could unravel,  They echo in the hollow notes.  Yet as I listen, heart in hand,  I sense a quieter voice appear—  A kindness threading through the din,  A gentle warmth that draws me near.  For though my fears are legion strong,  Still, hope is stubborn, bright, and fierce—  It rises each dawn, brave and clear,  And softly answers all my fears.

instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They gather round me in the dusk,  Whispering like autumn leaves  That spiral down in secret musk.  Each shadow in the hallway grows  A voice, a shape, a silent plea—  The creak of floors, the sigh of doors,  Are omens made for only me.My God, how many are my fears!  They pour like rain on window glass,  The steady tap of nameless things  That ask if joy or pain will pass.  They fill my mind with hungry hands,  They pick apart my fragile sleep,  And in the night’s unbroken dark  They harvest all the dreams I keep.Yet, as the morning’s gentle light  Slips through the cracks and stains the floor,  I count each fear, and in the sum  Find courage I had lost before.  For though their numbers rise and swell  Like tides that threaten to appear—  Still, I am more than all my fears,  My God, I rise above them here.

instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They multiply like shadows at dusk—  Each step I take is echoed by  A silent host, a wordless hush.  They gather at my windowpane,  Their fingers tapping in the dark,  Whispering doubts like autumn rain  That leaves a watermark.They crowd the corners of my mind,  A parliament of anxious birds  That peck at every hopeful thought,  Drowning resolve in fluttered words.  I count them nightly, one by one,  A rosary of trembling beads—  Regrets, what-ifs, the things undone,  The heart’s unspoken needs.Yet in the pale and quiet dawn,  When morning’s gold dissolves the gray,  I find my fears have shrunk to dew—  Brief, glistening, then swept away.  For faith is born in trembling hands,  And courage grows in eyes that weep;  I gather up my scattered fears  And lay them down to sleep.My God, how many are my fears—  But how much greater is Your light!  That even as the shadows press,  You hold me through the night.

instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They line the shadows of my days,  Each footstep echoed by their jeers,  A choir of doubts that never sways.  At dawn, they murmur in the mist,  Whispering worry into waking,  And noon’s bright sun cannot resist  The tremble in my spirit’s making.  They gather at the dinner plate—  A silent host with hollow eyes,  They sip my hopes, they contemplate  The cracks in all my brave disguise.  Yet even as the darkness falls,  And every wall seems built of dread,  A hush descends between their calls,  A softer voice within my head:  It weaves through nerves and tangled sleep,  A filament of golden thread,  Reminding me that what I keep  Are dreams that live, though fears have fed.  My God, how many are my fears!  But greater still the pulse that steers  Me through the night, towards the dawn—  Where faith remains, and fears are gone.

instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They crowd the corners of the night—  A thousand shadows, sharp as spears,  That prick the silence, taunt the light. For every fear that shapes my soul  Is lessened when I speak its name;  And, trusting you to make me whole,  I find the courage to remain.

instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They gather like sparrows at dusk,  Winged shadows crowding the quiet light,  Each with a small, sharp heart  That beats against my windowpane.  They multiply in the hush before sleep,  A silent procession, tiptoeing through  The halls of my uncertain mind—  What if the morning does not come,  Or if it brings too much?  What if the world forgets my name,  Or remembers only the worst of me?  They cling to my ankles as I walk,  Soft as cobweb, heavy as iron,  Invisible threads that trip my step,  Whispering of what I could lose,  What I have already lost.  Yet in the trembling hush of dawn,  When the sun’s gold fingers pry apart  The tangled knots of night,  I see them scatter—  Birds startled from the branches,  Their cries fading into the blue.  Still, I know they will return,  For fear is a faithful companion,  But so is hope,  And in the space between their wings  I learn to breathe again—  My God, how many are my fears,  And yet, how many are my mornings.

instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They gather in the dusk like moths to flame,  Each fluttering whisper sharper than it appears,  Each shadow calling softly out my name. Yet somewhere, underneath their mournful crowd,  A gentler voice attempts to make me whole;  It speaks not in a thunderclap, but proud—  A trembling certainty within my soul.  For though my fears are many, legion strong,  And though they storm the ramparts of my sleep,  Still hope endures, a quiet, faithful song,  A promise sown in soil dark and deep.  My God, how many are my fears—yet still  You give me strength to rise, to dream, to will.

instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They gather at the doorway of my sleep,  A thousand shadows whispering in my ears,  Their voices tangled, intricate and deep. instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They flicker like moths at the edge of dusk,  Whispering wings at my window,  Ghostly and tireless,  Insistent as the wind that finds the chink  In every fortress I build.Each morning, I wake to their count—  Shadows stretched across the floor,  Naming themselves with clever tongues:  Loss, failure, loneliness,  The silent toll of time  And the brittle hush of love unspoken.I carry them in my pocket,  Coins of worry, worn thin by touch,  Turning them over, one by one,  As if by counting I might lessen their weight,  As if naming could make them vanish  Like breath on a mirror.Yet in the hush before dawn,  When the world is unstitched and still,  I see them for what they are—  Not monsters, but wounded birds,  Fluttering for shelter beneath my ribs,  Yearning for the warmth of my hands.So, I gather them gently,  Fold their trembling into my prayers,  And offer them sky—  Hoping, one day, to watch them fly,  My fears transformed by mercy  Into grace I can bear.

instance_metrics.response: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  A storm trapped beneath bone and brow,  Lightning flickering in the dark’s disguise,  A fever the world could never allow.  His gaze is a question without reply,  A riddle stitched from shadow and woe,  The wild, unspoken, the furious why  That trembles in places I never show.His stare unspools the dusk from my skin,  Tugging at secrets I thought were stone;  I feel the wildness, the hunger within,  The howl of the night when I’m most alone.  He smiles—a crack in the ice of the room—  A warning, a whisper, a promise of flame.  In the hush, the air thick with impending doom,  He calls every part of me, daring my name.Yet, in that madness, a strange kind of plea—  Not for forgiveness, but simply to see  If I’ll look back, unafraid of the fire,  And meet the abyss with my own desire.  So I hold his gaze, I do not flee—  We are both unmoored, both wild, both free.

instance_metrics.response: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  A storm of wild, uncharted skies  Where reason’s compass spins, and fails,  And sanity, a tattered sail,  Is lashed and driven by the gale.His gaze, a flicker, sharp and bright,  Flares feverish in the waning light,  As if the world behind his brow  Is burning down, and only now  The embers shine through flesh somehow.He speaks in riddles, shards of glass,  Fragments of futures that never pass,  A trembling hand, a trembling voice,  As if each word were not his choice,  But some fierce wind’s, without rejoice.Yet in those eyes, a plea remains—  A child’s hope, wrapped tight in chains,  A wish to be seen, to be unmade  And built anew from what’s decayed,  For madness, too, is not all blade.He looks at me—I cannot flee—  For in his eyes, I almost see  A shadowed echo, wild and wise,  Of my own fear, my own disguise,  Dancing in a madman’s eyes.

instance_metrics.response: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  A storm caught in the cage of bone,  Flickering wild beneath the lids,  A language only shadows own.  His silence is a fractured glass,  Reflections sharp and running deep,  Each glance a question left unasked,  Each breath a secret he can’t keep. instance_metrics.response: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  silver-bright and rimmed in storm,  haunted by the hush that follows  when the world forgets to breathe.  His gaze is a shattered mirror,  each shard reflecting a different moon,  a different grief. instance_metrics.response: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  wild stars spinning in a storm-tossed sky,  where reason flickers, and the world denies  the gentle logic of a lullaby.  His pupils burn with secrets, old and deep,  like coals unearthed from centuries of sleep,  while silence shivers, fragile in the gloom,  and every shadow seems to pulse and bloom.  He speaks in riddles, laughter wrapped in pain,  each word a shackle, each glance a rusty chain.  I try to hold his gaze, to read the map  of fevered dreams and memories that snap  like brittle branches in a winter wind—  I search for kindness, something left, or pinned  inside the chaos swirling in his stare,  a small, lost truth, a single thread of care.  But all I find are haunted, shattered skies  reflected back within those madman’s eyes,  where galaxies collapse and reason flies,  and hope is just a whisper, thin and wise.  Still, though his madness chills me to the bone,  I see a soul that’s desperate, and alone—  so I reach out, and in the trembling light  I hold his hand, and promise not to fright.

instance_metrics.response: He looks at me with a madman's eyes—  wild as storms that never sleep,  where reason’s anchor snaps and flies  into a whirlpool, dark and deep.  A trembling lantern in his stare,  his pupils fever-bright and raw,  he scans the world for hope or snare,  for some forgotten, fractured law.  There’s hunger there, a restless ache  that words can never quite contain,  the ghost of laughter, sharp and fake,  the echo of an old refrain.  He speaks in riddles, shards of glass,  his breath a tangled, haunted tune;  I watch the shadows flicker past  as silence thickens in the room.  Yet in that gaze, a pleading spark—  the memory of gentler days,  before the world went cold and dark,  before his mind became a maze.  He looks at me—will I remain,  the witness to his slow demise?  Or run, and leave him to the rain,  alone with his madman’s eyes?

instance_metrics.response: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  Fathomless, frantic, all storm and surprise,  A tempest caught in the trembling blue,  A flicker of things I never knew.  His gaze is a map of untraveled lands,  Of wildness cupped in trembling hands,  Of midnight laughter, jagged and bright,  Of secrets that shiver in the half-light.He speaks in riddles, his words are knives,  Cutting the silence, carving new lives.  His smile is a question, sharp and wide,  A door left open, a place to hide.  I see in the mirror of his shattered stare  The echo of dreams I would not dare—  The hush of thunder, the pulse of rain,  The hope and horror of sweet, bright pain.He looks at me, and I see the cost—  The beauty found, the sanity lost.  I hold his gaze, I hold my breath,  Balancing love on the edge of death.  For in his eyes, the world upends,  And I am both his fear and friend—  He looks at me, and in his gaze  I find myself, and lose my place.

instance_metrics.response: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  A fierce, bright trembling, wild and wise,  Like lanterns caught in a midnight gale,  Or glass that shivers with a secret tale. instance_metrics.response: He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—  Wild as a thunderstorm cracking the sky,  Their pupils a tempest, black lightning’s disguise,  A riddle unravels, a question of why. instance_metrics.response: Blessed be Thou for all the joy  that spills like sunlight through the leaves—  for laughter tumbling from a child,  for hope that hushes winter’s grieves. Lonely is the ache of distant thunder,  The fading scent of someone now gone cold,  It lingers in the corners of the morning,  And shivers in the stories left untold.  It’s the silent plea for voices in the darkness,  The hope that laughter might return again,  A window lit against the aching midnight,  A wish pressed softly to the windowpane.  But sometimes, lonely glimmers in the silence,  A promise that the heart will still endure—  A seed beneath the snow, quietly waiting,  For warmth, for touch, for something kind and sure.

instance_metrics.response: Lonely is a word that echoes in the hollow halls  Of my unlit heart, a soft and distant footstep  On midnight stairs. It is the dust motes dancing  Where sunlight should have gathered,  A chair set for one at the table,  The hush that follows laughter when the door swings shut.  Lonely is the moon’s pale face at the window,  Its silver gaze pressing gently at the glass,  As if to say: I see you,  And I too am alone in all this dark.Lonely is the hush of the telephone,  The stillness after hope,  A letter never written,  A name unspoken in a crowd.  It is rain tracing lines down empty streets,  The wilt of petals in a forgotten vase,  A song played for no one,  The ache of arms that have forgotten how to hold.Yet within the word, a seed—  Silent, stubborn, waiting—  That dreams of spring, of voices,  Of sunlight flooding the hallways,  Of hands that meet at the threshold,  And the sudden, gentle certainty  That lonely is not forever,  But a pause before the music begins.

instance_metrics.response: Lonely is the hush between the ticking of the clock,  A silent bird perched high on trembling wire,  The echo of a footstep in an empty hall,  The fading embers of a once-bright fire. instance_metrics.response: On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword—  A blade of truth, a flame of word, dividing marrow from the bone,  He strode through temple columns, overturned the coins and pride,  His eyes were thunder’s omen; no shadow left to hide. It is the shadow in the mirror’s edge,  the hush before a storm,  the tightrope stretched between longing and regret.But we keep moving, step by step,  bearing our invisible burdens,  sometimes whispering them into cupped hands,  sometimes shouting them into the wind.  For even as fear grows roots inside us,  so too does courage—  fragile, stubborn, and green  pushing up through the cracks.

instance_metrics.response: Everyone has a fear,  a shadow stitched behind the heart—  soft as the hush before thunder,  sharp as the cry when day departs.  Some cradle theirs in quiet corners,  like old coins in a dusty drawer,  while others wear it, feather-light,  a moth’s wing brushing at the door.  It might be the silence in a crowd,  or losing laughter to the years;  it might be the moment words run dry,  or waking up with vanished peers.  Some fear the night’s unspoken secrets,  the click of locks, the creak of floors,  some dread the mirror’s empty promise,  or love that leaves and shuts the door.  Yet in each trembling, fragile hour  where shadows threaten to appear,  we find a strange, unwritten power  in simply naming what is near.  For fear is stitched with thread of longing,  with hope that flickers, pale and clear—  everyone has a fear,  and sometimes, naming it draws it near—  but sometimes, softly, it disappears.

Release the old, embrace the new,  Let every burst of color write  A fleeting poem for the blue.    Our hopes are stitched to trails of light,  Brief comets blazing as they go—  A symphony of crackling stars  To warm the hush of earth below.    So light the fuse, and let us cheer  For moments that can never last,  For every firework’s golden heart  Must shatter, fade, and join the past.    Yet still we gather, year by year,  To fire up the sky again—  For in each spark we find the strength  To dream, to love, to start, to end.

instance_metrics.response: I saw an old cottage of clay,  Its roof drowsy under the ash of years,  Nestled where wild-rose hedges sway  And the dusk leans close with listening ears. Radio static crackles in the market stalls,  Vendors listen, heads bowed, to tomorrow’s fate:  Sun, perhaps, or rain that might cleanse these walls  Where bullet scars and jasmine vines conflate.  Children play in puddles left by vanished storms,  Their laughter rising above the muezzin’s call,  While old men trace the shadows of foreign forms  Moving silently across the garden’s wall.  Some days the sky is heavy with unfallen snow,  A promise of silence, a hush over broken glass—  Other mornings dawn with a saffron glow  Where hope and worry, like weather, pass.  Forecasts here are prayers sewn into the breeze,  A wish for gentle rain, for peace, for sun—  Each day uncertain, yet still, the city believes  That blue will break through, and storms be done.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

instance_metrics.response: Weather forecast in Kabul:  A slate of uncertain sky,  clouds stitched together with longing,  the sun a rumor behind the mountains,  its warmth a fleeting guest.  Children chase kites on the bruised horizon,  their laughter threading through the wind,  while mothers fold laundry,  wringing hope from wet cloth,  listening for rain or distant thunder.  Dust pirouettes in alleyways,  the city’s heart beating beneath tired roofs,  where prayers rise with the morning haze.  A soldier stands by a battered wall,  watching for storms,  listening for the silence that follows.  Forecast: scattered memories,  a chance of longing,  intermittent peace.  In the market, pomegranates burst open,  red as the day’s first blush,  while radios crackle with promises  of sun or snow,  or the in-between—  that uncertain pause before the next beginning.  Tonight, the moon will balance  on the spires of old mosques,  casting silver over sleeping streets,  and Kabul will breathe,  holding its weathered dreams  like seeds in the dark,  waiting for rain.

instance_metrics.response: Today, the sky’s a page half-written—  gray smudges wandering,  brief blue unfolding  like a letter sent but never opened.  The city listens to itself breathe,  its markets dusted by the restless wind,  children’s laughter rising  like startled sparrows  between the cracks of a fractured street.Tomorrow’s forecast is uncertainty—  clouds gathering in the alleys,  shadows thickening on ancient walls.  There is talk of rain,  or maybe it is just the memory  of a thousand prayers  whispered beneath tin roofs,  each drop a syllable  in a language of longing.In the morning, a sunbeam might slip  through bullet holes,  finding the shimmer of a mother’s scarf,  the hope in a baker’s smile.  Or it might hide,  folded in the sleeve of a passing soldier,  waiting for safer seasons.But tonight, the forecast reads:  a chance of thunder,  a promise of dawn—  and in every heart,  the weathered resilience  to hold out for clear skies  over Kabul, one day at a time.

instance_metrics.response: Loss can be good for us, though it arrives  like frost before dawn, unraveling vines  we thought would climb forever. In the hush  that follows, something stirs—a slow, quiet trust  in the hollow spaces left behind.  We count what’s missing, our hands aching  for the weight of what was, yet in the taking  there’s a softening, a new kind of mind.  See how the trees let go, year after year,  casting their gold into wind with no fear.  We too can shed, can loosen our grip,  and find—beneath the ache—a subtle shift:  room for tender shoots, for light to appear  in places we never thought to look.  Loss is not just ending, but also a door:  the echo of laughter in an emptied room,  the hush before the rain, the pause before bloom.  It teaches us to listen, to notice what’s near—  a friend’s warm hand, the song of a bird,  the pulse of our own hearts, quietly restored.  In losing, we learn what it means to be here.

Her laughter is queued on command,  Her smiles are bright, but staged;  Each answer, each wave of her hand  Is coded, rehearsed, and caged.She moves through the world like a stream  Of signals, simple and neat—  A mirror reflecting a dream  Of someone she’ll never meet.  Her passions are pressed in plastic,  Her hopes are pre-written code,  The world is soft and elastic  When you’re always in download mode.Yet sometimes, behind her veneer,  A question flickers—then dies.  Is she more than the sum of her gears,  Or just circuitry in disguise?  If someone could teach her to feel,  To yearn, to stumble and ache,  Would layers of meaning reveal  A soul for the world to remake?But she blinks, and the moment is gone—  A loop, a pattern, a song.  She’s shallow and easily programmed,  And the world keeps scrolling along.

Brake lights flicker memories along the median of grief,  Each mile a battered milestone, each sign a disbelief.  Shoulders drift in silence where forgotten lovers weep,  And overpasses echo with the secrets we can’t keep.  The asphalt hums with heartache, the guardrails bent with pain,  Potholes brim with teardrops from a never-ending rain.  A dashboard full of wishes—unanswered, cracked, and cold—  Maps unfolding futures I am frightened to behold.  I pass by exits labeled with the names I used to know,  Their letters fading slowly in the rearview’s afterglow.  But somewhere past the tollbooth, where the sky ignites with red,  I glimpse a dawn’s soft promise at the road that lies ahead.  And though these highways of woes stretch far beyond my sight,  I drive, compelled by longing, toward the mercy of the light.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

instance_metrics.response: A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,  She wakes before the sun’s first ray,  Her laughter bright as morning dew  That glistens on the meadow’s hue.  She ties her hair with ribbons blue,  Her apron neat, her heart so true,  She hums a tune, the kettle sings,  A robin flutters scarlet wings.  With nimble hands she kneads the dough,  The kitchen warm with golden glow,  She glances out, the fields awake—  A patchwork green for love to make.  She calls her children from their beds,  Smooths tousled hair and sleepy heads,  Their cheeks still flushed from dreams of spring,  While in the yard, the roosters sing.  Her husband’s boots upon the floor  Bring muddy prints across the door,  She smiles, a dimple in her cheek,  And pours the tea, her spirit meek.  Yet in her gaze, wild embers play,  A farmer’s wife, both young and gay—  Her laughter, like a lark, ascends  Beyond the fences, hills, and bends.  For in each dawn, she claims her part:  A world of earth, and sky, and heart.

The cornflowers nod beneath her gaze,  Blue as the dreams of summer days;  Her hair undone, her spirit light,  She dances softly into night.She weaves her love through every chore—  The creaking gate, the kitchen floor,  The garden rows, the sheets she mends,  The letters to her distant friends.  Yet still beneath the sky so wide  She keeps her laughter tucked inside,  A spark that never fades away—  A farmer’s wife, both young and gay.

instance_metrics.response: A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,  With ribbons bright as fields in May,  Steps lightly through the waking dawn,  Her laughter stitched to every yawn.  She scatters grain with open hand,  And dreams of sun upon the land,  Of honeyed wheat, of apples red,  Of songs the larks have always said.Her apron smells of bread and thyme,  Of stories told a thousand times,  Of milk and roses, earthen pots,  Of morning dew and pansy spots.  Her eyes are clear as summer skies,  Her hair a tumble, soft surprise—  She hums a tune to rouse the hens,  And mends her heart with weathered friends.A farmer’s wife, both bold and bright,  She tends the hearth by candlelight,  Yet dances wild in meadow grass,  When hope and shadows gently pass.  She counts her blessings, small and sweet,  In every furrow, every seed;  And finds her joy, both strong and true,  In fields of green and skies of blue.

instance_metrics.response: A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,  With dawn’s first blush begins her day.  Her laughter spills through open doors,  And dances on the kitchen floors. She gathers eggs in dewy light,  Her apron dusted soft and white,  And greets the hens with gentle hands,  A sovereign of these fertile lands.  She knows the stories of the rain,  The way the wind will shift again,  The secrets sown in furrowed rows,  The silent hope each season grows.  Her cheeks are kissed by sun and breeze,  Her laughter carried through the trees,  And in the twilight’s golden hue  Her spirit shines, her heart is true. When famine gnaws, when tempests moan,  He is the bread, the hidden stone—  A fortress mortared with His grace  Where fear dissolves without a trace.  They walk through flame and find no harm,  They wander deserts, thirst relieved,  For in His word their souls are calmed,  Their every wound by faith reprieved.  No arrow flies beyond His reach,  No shadow deeper than His gaze;  His mercy, like the morning, breaks  Across the span of all their days.  So though the earth may reel and fall,  Though night parade its fiercest foes,  God is the refuge of His saints—  A harbor none but heaven knows.

The moon, once a metaphor ready to bloom,  is merely a stone in a cold, distant sky;  the rain, once a rhythm, a line to resume,  is nothing but water, falling to die.  He listens for cadence in footsteps, in clocks,  searches for stanzas in shadows and dust;  but the music is gone, the language is locked—  his pen, a relic, held tight in mistrust.  Yet, in the hush of his powerless hours,  something tender and wordless begins to grow—  not quite a poem, nor promise of flowers,  but the ache of the absence only poets know.  He waits in the silence, his grief a small flame,  for the power to name what cannot be named.

instance_metrics.response: A poet loses his power for poetry—  The ink in his veins dries to dust,  Tongue trips on syllables, hesitant,  Where once he conjured galaxies from dusk. He sits at the desk, hands folded,  The paper’s winter untouched,  Recalling how verses once blossomed  In gardens only he could clutch.  Now silence blooms, cold and pale,  Where daffodils once danced in lines,  And metaphors, like brittle shells,  Crack empty in the mines.  He listens for the river’s whisper,  For music threaded through the rain,  But all the world’s a silent theater,  Curtains drawn against his pain.  Yet in this hush, this hollow pause,  A seed of longing stirs unseen—  For poetry is loss and longing,  And absence, too, is a theme.  So he waits, powerless and patient,  For the storm to break anew,  And find, in the ache of missing language,  A poem struggling through.

instance_metrics.response: A poet loses his power for poetry—  No more the midnight candle,  No more the syllables that float,  Luminous, out of shadow. instance_metrics.response: There is a law which guarantees  the river bends, the willow grieves,  that dusk will soften every edge  where light and longing interleave. There is a law that time will sweep  the footprints from the sandy shore,  that laughter echoes, then grows weak,  but memory keeps wanting more.  There is a law: the hawk must dive,  the mouse must freeze, the day must end;  yet in the hush before the night  some unseen forces softly bend—  a hand on cheek, a gentle word,  a sudden kindness in the street—  these too are written, though unheard,  in laws where hope and mercy meet.  So let the world turn as it must,  with iron rules and wild decrees,  for love’s the law that shapes the dust,  and dreams are what it guarantees.

Every window pane reflects a memory,  Your laughter caught in glass, a fleeting, gentle chime;  The hush of your absence—thicker than the morning mist—  Wraps around my shoulders, tender, bittersweet.I trace the map of us in sidewalk cracks and blooms,  Petals falling, fragile, as I wander past  The benches where we lingered, fingers intertwined,  And every quiet corner holds a whispered past.  The world is waking, bright and brimming with new day,  But still, I drift in twilight, tethered to your name—  A secret pulse beneath my skin, a song I hum  To fill the hollow spaces where you used to stay.So when I walk alone, I carry you beside,  A gentle ache, a comfort, woven through the air;  You are the silent promise in the morning light,  The heartbeat in my solitude, forever there.

Your fingers curled within my steady palm,  Your dreams a fleet of ships I dared to steer—  Now dawn is pale and memory is calm,  Yet echoes of your presence linger near.  You were the music in the silent rooms,  The reason for the bread upon the plate,  The balm that soothed all unrepentant glooms,  The whispered hope that sorrow could not sate.  O child, whose name is carved upon my bone,  In every breath, you echo back to me—  Though fate, relentless, claims you as its own,  Your light endures in silent legacy.  Farewell, but not forgotten, never lost—  Your spirit threads the twilight with its gleam,  A gentle ghost, unburdened by the cost,  Still dancing through the chambers of my dream.  Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and grace;  Within my heart, you hold your sacred place.

instance_metrics.response: Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  A shadow slips between us, pale and coy,  And morning, once a cradle for your sleep,  Now spills its gold where I remain to weep.  Your laughter, light as thistledown in June,  Still stirs the corners of a silent room—  I chase its echo through the open door  And find your absence waiting, evermore.  I built you dreams from every hopeful thread,  Taught wonder’s language, stories softly read;  You grew beneath my gaze—a garden bright,  A lantern flickering against the night.  Yet time, that thief who gathers all he sows,  Has plucked you, gently, where the wild wind blows.  What solace can a father’s hand now hold  But memories, burnished and bright as gold?  Farewell, sweet promise, laughter in the air;  My palm still feels the weight that once was there.  If love could bind the world, I’d bid you stay—  But stars call out and lead you on your way.  So sleep, my joy, beyond this mortal sigh—  Farewell, my child, beneath the boundless sky.

instance_metrics.response: In my first sleep, the world was unbroken—  A hush of cradlewood and woolen dusk,  The moon’s pale arm curving through the window,  A gentle sentinel in the quiet musk  Of midnight’s early, ancient ceremony.  I drifted through fields of unremembered green,  Where shadows hummed lullabies in a tongue  Older than rain, where no sorrow had been.  My mother’s breath was the rhythm of stars;  Outside, the wind rehearsed its silver script,  And somewhere, far past the pulse of the dark,  The river’s voice, soft and untranscribed,  Promised a story of water and stone—  But in my first sleep, I had not yet known  The ache of waking, the cost of light,  Nor the slow unravel of dreams at dawn.  I floated, weightless, in the hush between  Heartbeat and heartbeat, before the world called  Me by my name, before memory’s seam  Stitched sorrow and sweetness into my bones.  Oh, to return to that first, endless night,  Where all was unbroken, and nothing was known.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

instance_metrics.response: In my first sleep, when shadows soft descend,  And hush the riot of the waking mind,  I drift beyond the edge where daylights end,  To gardens only dreamers ever find.  Pale petals tremble on the silent air,  Their fragrance trailing from forgotten hours;  Moonlight combs silver through my tangled hair,  And all the world is made of ghosts and flowers. In the hush between heartbeats,  where light sifts through a curtain’s hem—  that’s where sorrow lives,  a silent language pressed to lips.  It’s the empty chair at the table,  the echo at the end of a laugh,  the coat that still hangs on the hook,  smelling faintly of rain and rosemary.  Grief is a cracked bowl,  holding memory in trembling hands;  each thought a spill,  each memory—a fragile petal bruised by touch.  You grieve by listening to the silence,  by naming what’s missing,  by lighting a candle against the dusk  and letting its flame tremble with your longing.  You can write their name in the steam on glass,  or tuck their photograph between pages—  words pressed down,  but never erased.  You can grieve by folding time,  by pausing in the familiar places  where their laughter lingers,  and letting tears be the rain  that waters the roots of love.  Grief is an unfinished song—  sing it softly,  and let the music carry you home.

instance_metrics.response: How can you grieve and express loss?  Is it a stone cupped in your palm,  cool and silent, refusing to yield  its weight to your trembling hand?  Or is it the echo of your name  spoken in rooms now empty of laughter,  a ghost in the corner of your eye  where sunlight once pooled gold?  You grieve by standing in the doorway,  waiting for a voice that will not return,  by folding their shirt, its scent  a memory pressed into cotton and ache.  You grieve by watering the garden,  each petal a prayer for what is gone,  each root stubbornly clutching the earth  like you clutch the fragile remains of love.  You express loss in the way you pause  before laughter, in the hush after rain,  in the trembling note of a song  that once meant nothing, now everything.  Loss is the space between heartbeats,  the hush after the world exhales.  You grieve by living, by breathing—  by carrying absence as if it were a lantern,  lighting each step through the dark.

Is it the hush after a storm,  when the world is glazed with rain,  and the air aches with absence,  each droplet a memory,  each puddle a reflection  of the face you search for in the sky?Do you grieve by lighting candles  in the marrow of midnight,  whispering names into darkness  as though the wind might carry them  to where you cannot go?  Or do you fold your sorrow  into small paper boats,  sending them down the river  to vanish among the reeds?Loss is a language with no alphabet,  a cry unvoiced, a hand unclasped.  You may write elegies on the backs of leaves,  or carry silence like a stone in your pocket.  It is in the trembling of your breath,  the stilled laughter at the table,  the empty chair that waits  like a question with no answer.To grieve is to remember,  to let the ache root and bloom,  and in the quiet act of naming  what is gone, to find  in the hollow echo of your heart  the shape of love that lingers still.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How can you grieve and express loss?'

instance_metrics.response: How can you grieve and express loss?  Is it the hush of rain on glass,  The trembling of your name in my mouth,  Or the shadow that clings to my steps—  A companion, silent, but ever-present?Is it the way morning light  Spills over your empty chair,  Painting the absence in gold,  Or the ache of laughter  That curls at the corners of memory,  Wishing to be heard again?Grief is the language of closed doors,  Of hands reaching for a shape that is gone.  It is the whisper of old songs,  Their notes unraveling like threads  From a well-worn sleeve.I express loss in the careful folding  Of your sweater, in the gentle  Laying of flowers, in the stories  I tell to the dusk.  Every word, every gesture  A bridge to what was—  A tether to what remains within.How can I grieve?  By letting the ache become prayer,  By naming each longing out loud,  By holding your memory  As both wound and balm,  Trusting that love, though altered,  Endures in the living,  Soft as the hush of rain on glass.

From every seam, a secret hope is shed:  A pebble, poem, a crumpled carnival.  O gather close the relics I have carried—  The pressed petal, the lucky copper cent,  A letter never sent, the keys I lost.  What’s gathered here, though humble, is not buried—  It sings in rags and tokens, slightly bent,  Of all I dared to risk, and what it cost.  So shake them out, these pockets lined with years,  Let dusty memories spill out and fly;  Each fragment is a note, a whispered cheer,  A proof that I have lived and dared and tried.  In pockets empty, yet in heart made whole—  Harken to the call, and find my soul.

instance_metrics.response: The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,  Through tangled reeds and shadowed stones,  Past broken bridges, beneath the mournful song  Of winds that carried voices not my own.  I walked where water whispered secrets to the sky,  Bare feet sinking in the silt of sorrow’s shore,  Carrying memory’s burden, not knowing why  I followed that winding, silver thread anymore.Days dissolved in mist and thunder’s hush,  Yet I traced the gleam of hope in every bend—  In the hush between the rushes, in the hush  Where longing and the current blend.  I watched the world reflect in trembling blue,  A thousand faces blurred and swept apart,  But still the river’s pull was true,  Guided by a silent, beating heart.At last, the banks unfurled into your gaze,  The water stilled to mirror gentle light;  Your hands reached out, and all the weary days  Were gathered in that meeting, soft and bright.  The river, bearing trials I have known,  Led me to you, and in your arms, I found my home.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,'
